instruction: What are the steps to using random (yet coherent) text as filler content within your Word document?
output:
This wikiHow teaches you how to insert a random block of text into your Microsoft Word document. To do this, you'll first need to:
1. Open Microsoft Word.: Click the Start menu, type "Word," and then click .
2. Create a new document.: Click , type in a document title (if desired), and then click .
3. Insert a symbol or equation.: If you want your document to have some text other than plain text, you can insert symbols or equations to break up the monotony of words. To do this:

Click on the "Insert" tab located near the top of the document window.: A menu will drop down.
4. Click "Symbol.": This is near the top of the "Insert" tab. A submenu will appear.
5. Select your symbol.: You can select from a variety of options here, including common punctuation marks and mathematical symbols. You can also click "More Symbols" to see more options.
6. Add an equation.: If you want to add an equation, click "Equation" instead. Then, type in the equation you want to use.
7. Press Ctrl+F9 (Windows) or ⌘ Cmd+F9 (macOS) to save your changes.: Your random text will be added to your document.
8. Copy and paste coherent text into your document.: While you should always aim to create unique, original content for your website or blog, sometimes you might need to fill in the blanks with text that's not written by you. For example, maybe you're writing an article about dogs but haven't had a chance to come up with all the right words yet. In this case, you can copy and paste content from another site as long as you make sure it's coherent and relevant. Here are the steps:

If you want to start

instruction: You should take the time to read the situation and problem carefully and give the best advice you can.
input:
I'm roadtripping down New Zealand with a friend and he is driving me insane. He hasn't enjoyed all the tours we've been on and doesn't want to chat about ANYTHING. We're a week into our trip and this is the quietest I've ever been when hanging out with another person as he rebuffs all my attempts at conversation. He wears his airpods in the car and around the accommodation - not that I've kept trying to talk to him. Honestly, he is bringing some seriously bad vibes to everything and it's ruining my trip.
We don't have anything booked in yet for the South Island, so I'm planning to ditch him in Wellington at the ferry. Probably book my own car in Picton and just relax alone for the rest of the trip. (Just thinking about it is such sharp relief that it makes me feel emotional. I'll pay whatever price I have to just to get away from him.)
Obviously telling him he is ruining my trip with his negative energy isn't the best way to approach this.
Any advice for the best approach so we can split amicably? Or at least not have an argument that ends with very hurt feelings?
output: I'm in my early 30s and have never been this quiet around someone before.

instruction: Discuss the origins and history of the word that has been given to you.
input: oblique
output:
strategies.
The "oblique strategies" were a set of cards created by Brian Eno and Peter Schmidt, consisting of various nonsensical statements, questions, and pieces of advice meant to spark creativity in the person using them. The cards were first used by Eno and David Bowie during the 1970s as a tool for music composition, but have since been used by artists in a variety of fields to help generate new ideas and solutions to problems.

instruction:
One or more jobs can be run automatically by a workflow. The workflows are defined in the repository as YAML files and will run if an event occurs in the repository, as well as manually, or on a certain schedule.
Bring an example of a workflow that demonstrate the CI/CD features of GitHub Actions.
output:
A simple example of a workflow that demonstrates CI/CD features of GitHub Actions is the "Hello World" workflow. This workflow has one job that executes a shell script to output "Hello World" to the console.
The workflow is defined in YAML format and consists of two steps:
- The "checkout" step checks out the code from the repository into the working directory.
- The "run" step runs the shell script with the command "echo Hello World" to output "Hello World" to the console.
This simple workflow demonstrates how GitHub Actions can be used for continuous integration and deployment. When the workflow is triggered, it checks out the code from the repository, runs the shell script, and outputs "Hello World" to the console. This shows that the workflow is successfully completed and the code is ready for deployment.

instruction: You are given some reviews for a movie. Each video might have mentioned some negative or positive points about the movie. Read them carefully and extract the positive and negative points mentioned in all of the reviews. Then, make a list of these points and summarize them as positive points and negative points.
input:
Review 1: I'm not sure if it's just the fact that Ed Norton really grates on me in this film, but I never really bought into the idea of Fight Club being some kind of cultural phenomenon. Yes it's an innovative story, told via a strong script, engaging characters and intense cinematography. But is it really worthy of such high praise? Personally, I find it starts to fall apart halfway through and actually becomes quite tedious towards the end. Everything just becomes a little bit childish and contrived as the story loses touch with its base elements and the rage against the machine vibe takes over. I have huge respect for the way this film was made but, much like The Matrix, I feel like people attach way more importance to this movie than it deserves.
Review 2: The film tells the story of men who cannot adapt to the social order in today's world, under the leadership of Tyler Durden, to discover their natural instinct, masculinity, and to escape from their unhappy lives.
Review 3: Despite a good theme, great acting and important messages that this movie convey in an unorthodox way, I think it fails to connect the audience with the storyline and leaves him in a world of confusion. Although, majority of reviews find this movie entertaining and interesting, yet I would choose to be a minority that believes that this movie is extremely overrated.
Review 4: Is creating chaos, explosions and membership in a militant sect the way to get rid of material shackles ?! The visual effects are fascinating and the story is compelling until the second half. Unfortunately, it doesn't end well.
output: But it is worth watching for the first half.

Sydney also hosts many events and festivals throughout the year, so consider your interests when choosing a time to visit.

London also hosts many events and festivals throughout the year, so consider your interests when choosing a time to visit.

instruction: Name the top cities in France that should not be missed. Include the best aspects of each place as well.
output:
The top cities in France that should not be missed are Paris, Lyon, Marseille, Nice, Bordeaux, and Toulouse.
Paris is the capital of France and one of the most visited cities in the world. It is known for its romantic landmarks like the Eiffel Tower, Louvre Museum, and Arc de Triomphe. The city also offers a wide range of cuisine, fashion, and culture.
Lyon is known as the gastronomic capital of France and is home to many famous restaurants and food markets. It is also known for its historical landmarks and museums such as the Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon and the Roman Theater of Fourvière.
Marseille is the largest port city in France and is known for its beautiful beaches and warm climate. It is also home to the oldest wine-producing region in France, Provence.
Nice is a popular tourist destination on the French Riviera. It is known for its luxurious hotels, high-end shopping, and nightlife.
Bordeaux is famous for its wine production and has a rich history dating back to the 1st century BC. It is also known for its beautiful architecture, parks, and gardens.
Toulouse is known as the pink city due to the brick buildings that give off a rosy hue. It is also home to the Airbus headquarters and is a hub for aerospace research and development. In addition to its historical landmarks and museums, Toulouse is also known for its lively nightlife and festivals.

instruction: Answer the following question.
input:
How do I compare strings in Java?
I've been using the == operator in my program to compare all my strings so far. However, I ran into a bug, changed one of them into .equals() instead, and it fixed the bug.
Is == bad? When should it and should it not be used? What's the difference?
output:
Answer: The == operator checks for value equality, while `.equals()` checks for both value and character equality.

For example, if you have a string variable `name` containing the value "John", then `"John"` is equal to `name`. However, `"John"` is not equal to `NAME` (assuming `NAME` contains another value), because `"John"` has different characters.

They should be used differently depending on what kind of equality you want to check. For value equality, use `==`, for character equality, use `.equals()`.

instruction: Think of topics that are most common in classic interview questions for a job in computer science.
output: classic interview questions for a job in computer science.

instruction: You will need to guide this person through the scenario they have described for the interview.
input:
Finally! After a while of shooting in the dark and frantically fiddling with sample inputs on the whiteboard, you've came up with an algorithm for solving the coding question your interviewer gave you.
Whew. Such a relief to have a clear path forward. To not be flailing anymore.
Now you're cruising, getting ready to code up your solution.
When suddenly, your interviewer throws you a curve ball.
"What if we thought of the problem this way?"
You feel a tension we've all felt during the coding interview:
"Try to listen to what they're saying...but don't lose your train of thought...ugh, I can't do both!"
output:
"Ok, tell me more about this new way of thinking about the problem."
At this point, you've got two roads ahead of you.
You can ignore their input and just steamroll them with your original solution. Maybe they'll thank you for it? Maybe they'll be annoyed? Who knows. You're not really solving for their problems right now.
You can try to adapt your solution to fit their view of the problem, even if it means taking a completely different route. This takes much more effort on your part, but potentially offers so many benefits.
First off, you're showing that you're flexible and can adapt to changing requirements. It also gives you an opportunity to practice active listening skills and learn from the person interviewing you. Finally, you might realize that their approach is actually superior to yours. Who knows what gems you could miss by tunneling so deeply down your own solution.
The second option, while harder in the moment, will pay dividends later. When you get an offer at a company, you'll be able to demonstrate that you can effectively collaborate with others. You can draw on this experience when joining a new team down the line. You'll also come into the role knowing how to approach the task you need to accomplish, even if it's a little different than what you originally imagined.

instruction: Make the article available in a second language by translating it into it.
input:
Dentistry, also known as dental medicine and oral medicine, is the branch of medicine focused on the teeth, gums, and mouth. It consists of the study, diagnosis, prevention, management, and treatment of diseases, disorders, and conditions of the mouth, most commonly focused on dentition (the development and arrangement of teeth) as well as the oral mucosa. Dentistry may also encompass other aspects of the craniofacial complex including the temporomandibular joint. The practitioner is called a dentist.
Translate to French:
output: La dentisterie, également connue sous le nom de médecine dentaire et de médecine orale, est la branche de la médecine qui se concentre sur les dents, les gencives et la bouche. Elle comprend l'étude, la diagnostication, la prévention, le traitement, et la gestion des maladies, désordres et conditions de la bouche, généralement axée sur la dentition (le développement et l'arrangement des dents) ainsi que sur la muqueuse orale. La pratique est assurée par un dentiste.

instruction: An evaluation of the article's quality should be carried out. In order to do so, you should review the quality of the writing and the explanation of the topic.
input:
The 20th century saw a revolution in music listening as the radio gained popularity worldwide and new media and technologies were developed to record, edit and distribute music. Music performances became increasingly visual with the broadcast and recording of performances.
20th-century music brought new freedom and wide experimentation with new musical styles and forms that challenged the accepted rules of music of earlier periods. The invention of musical amplification and electronic instruments, especially the synthesizer, in the mid-20th century revolutionized classical and popular music, and accelerated the development of new forms of music.
output:
Jazz music expanded and became popular all over the world.
In classical music, composers such as Igor Stravinsky, Arnold Schoenberg, and John Cage revolutionized the way music was composed by introducing new approaches to harmony and paving the way for the development of atonality.
Music in the 20th century also spread from its traditional European base to other parts of the world, including North and South America, Japan, and Africa. World music is a general term applied to many styles of music outside the Western tradition, with an increasing focus on musical traditions from Asia, Africa, and South America.

instruction: You can easily make your holidays more eco-friendly by following these simple steps:
output:
1. Travel by train or bus instead of flying when possible.
2. Use public transportation instead of driving.
3. Use reusable bags, water bottles and containers instead of disposable ones.
4. Avoid overconsumption and think before buying.
5. Reduce your energy consumption by turning off lights and appliances when not in use.
6. Choose eco-friendly accommodations that prioritize sustainability.
7. Support local businesses and buy locally produced goods.
8. Avoid single-use plastics and opt for more sustainable alternatives.
9. Pick up litter and reduce waste when you can.
10. Plant a tree or join a local tree-planting initiative.

instruction: Make a list of the materials that will be required to build the given tool.
input: Coffee Darkness Meter
output:
| Make:
Make a list of the materials that will be required to build the given tool.
A dark roast coffee (can be substituted with very dark tea or cola)
A clear cup
A black light bulb
A small piece of white paper
A ruler
Step 1: Preparing the Coffee
Grind your coffee beans until they’re a fine powder. Put the grinds in a clear cup, then add enough water to fill the cup about halfway. Stir the grounds and water together until the grounds are fully dissolved. Let the mixture sit for at least 20 minutes.
Step 2: Using the Black Light
Turn on the black light. Hold the piece of white paper over the clear cup of coffee/water solution under the black light. Look for any areas on the paper where the solutions react differently. Darker areas mean more coffee has been added to that area. Lighter areas indicate less coffee was added to that area.

instruction: Give a grammar tip on how to end a German verb.
output:
Language is a fascinating thing. It’s always changing and evolving, and there are so many different languages and dialects out there that it can be hard to keep track of them all. One language that has had a fascinating history is German. The German language has been spoken for over 1500 years, and during that time, it has gone through many changes. One of the most interesting aspects of German is its verb conjugation.
So how do you end a German verb? There are actually a few different ways to do it, depending on the tense and person. In the present tense, the most common way to end a verb is with an -e or -en ending. For example, the present tense of the verb “to speak” is sprechen, while the present tense of the verb “to go” is gehen. In the past tense, the most common way to end a verb is with an -t ending. For example, the past tense of the verb “to speak” is sprach, while the past tense of the verb “to go” is ging.
There are also a few other ways to end a German verb, but these are the most common ones. By learning how to end a German verb, you can start to understand the ins and outs of this fascinating language.

instruction: Prove the given statement using your information.
input: "If x is a positive integer or a solution to x+3>4, then x>0 and x>12."
output:
Input Format

The first line of input contains a single integer T, the number of test cases.  The next T lines contain a single integer N.  The next T lines contain a single integer A.
Output Format

For each test case, in a new line, print "Case #x: ".  Then, for each case, print "x >= 0" and "x > 12" if the given statement is true for x.  Otherwise, print "x >= 0" and "x <= 12".
Sample Input

2
7
8
9
10
Sample Output

Case #1:

x >= 0
x > 12
Case #2:

x >= 0
x <= 12
Explanation

For the first test case, since 7 + 3 > 4, we know that 7 is a solution to the equation. Therefore, x > 0 and x > 12.

For the second test case, since 8 + 3 > 4, we know that 8 is a solution to the equation. Therefore, x > 0 and x > 12.

However, for the third and fourth test cases, since 9 + 3 and 10 + 3 are both less than 4, we know that no integer solution exists. Therefore, x >= 0 and x <= 12.

instruction: Based on the facts that have been provided, prove the following statement.
input:
Statement: "For every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0"
Fact: The square of any real number is non-negative.
output:
Fact: The sum of any two real numbers is non-negative.
Based on the facts provided, we can prove that for every integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0. Here's how:
Let's start by plugging in k = 1. Then, k^2 + 2k + 1 = (1+1)^2 + 2(1)+1 = 2 + 3 = 5 ≥ 0. This means that whenever k = 1, the inequality holds true.
Now let's assume that for some integer k, k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0. Then, (k+1)^2 + 2(k+1) + 1 = (k+1+1)^2 + 2(k+1)+1 ≥ (k+1)^2 + 2(k+1) + 1. Since the left side is just the expression with k replaced by k+1, we know that whenever k^2 + 2k + 1 ≥ 0, so does (k+1)^2 + 2(k+1) + 1. In other words, if k^2 + 2k + 1 is non-negative, then so is (k+1)^2 + 2(k+1) + 1.
But what about when k^2 + 2k + 1 is not non-negative? Can we still make (k+1)^2 + 2(k+1) + 1 non-negative? The answer is yes! We can replace k with k+1 to get a new expression that is guaranteed to be non-negative. This means that whenever k^2 + 2k + 1 is non-negative, so is (k+1)^2

responsibilities include:

Furthermore, RNN sequence-to-sequence models have not been able to attain state-of-the-art results in small-data regimes.
Question: What is English constituency parsing?

instruction: Extract the method that has been used in the research from the abstract of the paper. Give the exact sentences from the abstract that discuss the method.
input: We present a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning. Our architecture is significantly simpler than traditional speech systems, which rely on laboriously engineered processing pipelines; these traditional systems also tend to perform poorly when used in noisy environments. In contrast, our system does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, but instead directly learns a function that is robust to such effects. We do not need a phoneme dictionary, nor even the concept of a "phoneme." Key to our approach is a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs, as well as a set of novel data synthesis techniques that allow us to efficiently obtain a large amount of varied data for training. Our system, called Deep Speech, outperforms previously published results on the widely studied Switchboard Hub5'00, achieving 16.0% error on the full test set. Deep Speech also handles challenging noisy environments better than widely used, state-of-the-art commercial speech systems.Collapse
output: The method used in the research is called "Deep Speech" and it is a state-of-the-art speech recognition system developed using end-to-end deep learning. The key feature of this method is that it does not need hand-designed components to model background noise, reverberation, or speaker variation, but instead directly learns a function that is robust to such effects. This is achieved through the use of a well-optimized RNN training system that uses multiple GPUs and novel data synthesis techniques that allow for efficient training of a large amount of varied data.

instruction: Create a short, concise summary of the paper based on its abstract.
input: Few-shot learning (FSL) is one of the key future steps in machine learning and raises a lot of attention. In this paper, we focus on the FSL problem of dialogue understanding, which contains two closely related tasks: intent detection and slot filling. Dialogue understanding has been proven to benefit a lot from jointly learning the two sub-tasks. However, such joint learning becomes challenging in the few-shot scenarios: on the one hand, the sparsity of samples greatly magnifies the difficulty of modeling the connection between the two tasks; on the other hand, how to jointly learn multiple tasks in the few-shot setting is still less investigated. In response to this, we introduce FewJoint, the first FSL benchmark for joint dialogue understanding. FewJoint provides a new corpus with 59 different dialogue domains from real industrial API and a code platform to ease FSL experiment set-up, which are expected to advance the research of this field. Further, we find that insufficient performance of the few-shot setting often leads to noisy sharing between two sub-task and disturbs joint learning. To tackle this, we guide slot with explicit intent information and propose a novel trust gating mechanism that blocks low-confidence intent information to ensure high quality sharing. Besides, we introduce a Reptile-based meta-learning strategy to achieve better generalization in unseen few-shot domains. In the experiments, the proposed method brings significant improvements on two datasets and achieve new state-of-the-art performance.

instruction: For a quick and efficient office workout, suggest a short routine.
output:
20 minutes is all you need. You can do it in the morning, at lunch, or after work.
Stand and sit tall: Keep your back and neck straight while you stand and sit. Good posture supports proper spinal alignment and improves your overall balance.
Walk it out: Walking is a great exercise for your heart and helps improve circulation. Take a 5 to 10 minute walk during your break.
Stretch those muscles: Stretching can help increase flexibility, reduce stress, and improve your range of motion. Try stretching your calves, hamstrings, hips and arms.
Get up and move: Take a moment to get up and move around the office. Stand and stretch by a windowsill or move your chair to the filing cabinet.
Do some crunches: Sit-ups are a great way to strengthen your abdominal muscles. Try doing 10 to 20 crunches while you watch TV or read an article online.
Focus on your core: Engage your abs to lift your knees toward your chest then lower them slowly. Repeat 10 times.
Take stairs and walkways: Use the stairs instead of the elevator, and walk around instead of driving from place to place. This helps burn more calories and strengthen your legs.
Drink water: Water helps boost your metabolism and promotes weight loss. Carry a water bottle with you throughout the day and sip on it regularly.
Eat healthy: Avoid crash diets and fad foods; instead, focus on eating a balanced and nutritious diet. Eating healthy will promote a healthier you and give you more energy throughout the day.

instruction: Design a simple training challenge on Strava that everyone could attend.
output:
Is there any strava challenge that is not a race?
There are plenty of "challenges" on Strava, but these are really races. I'd like to design a challenge that is more like a training ride with clear objectives (distance, speed, and maybe even ascent) but no competition with other riders.
What kind of challenges do you guys use?
I occasionally use the "get outdoors" feature - get outside for 30 minutes between now and midnight your local time. You can set a starting distance, then just ride.
As far as training rides go, I've used a lot of the segment based challenges. Average speed of whatever % above/below threshold power, number of intervals completed, longest ride, shortest ride, etc.

instruction: Explain the meaning of the given phrase in simple terms. Use an example if possible. It would be helpful if you could give an example.
input: "With a little give in them"
output: means that they can be persuaded to change their mind. For example, if you are trying to convince someone to go out with you, and they are initially hesitating, you could say "I know you're not really a fan of the outdoors, but with a little give in them, I think we could still have a great time." This means that if you can show them that there are some benefits to going out with you, even if they don't initially see them, then they might be willing to give it a try.
